titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Hermann John Weigand Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Brook Abdu, Lucy Western, and Alison Clemens

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday May 4, 2019 at 07:11

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, subject files, writings, and personal papers. The correspondence includes letters with colleagues, students, and family friends concerning various topics, including views on articles published by Weigand and colleagues, different symposia, and administrative matters. The subject files include material pertaining to Weigand's research and teaching, and the writings include Weigand's notebooks and manuscripts, as well as writings of others.Material documenting Weigand's professional and family life is also present, as are audiocassettes of Weigand and his wife doing readings and dictating letters.

langmaterial.language: The collection is in English and German.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Mrs. Hermann Weigand, 1999. Gift of the Estate of Mary Koenig Weigand, 2017.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 22 (student recommendations) is restricted until January 1, 2050 as established by Yale Corporation regulations.
Box 19 (student records) from Accession 2017-m-0060 is restricted until January 1, 2044 as established by Yale Corporation regulations.

Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Hermann John Weigand Papers (MS 1759). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Hermann John Weigand was born in Philadelphia in 1892. Weigand received his bachelor's degree and a doctorate in Germanic studies from the University of Michigan, where he also taught from 1913 to 1918. Weigand then went on to teach at the University of Pennsylvania before his tenure at Yale, which began in 1929. He was a leading United States scholar of Germanic literature, with expertise in medieval literature, the age of Goethe and Romanticism, modern German poetry, and Henrik Ibsen. In 1933 his acclaimed study, Thomas Mann's Novel, Der Zauberberg; A Study, was published. Weigand taught at Yale for 32 years until retirement in 1961. He continued doing research and publishing articles, even though he lost his vision in 1965. Weigand died on September 3, 1985.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence, subject files, writings, and personal papers. The correspondence includes letters with colleagues, students, and family friends concerning various topics, including views on articles published by Weigand and colleagues, different symposia, and administrative matters. The subject files include material pertaining to Weigand's research and teaching, and the writings include Weigand's notebooks and manuscripts, as well as writings of others. Material documenting Weigand's professional and family life is also present, as are audiocassettes of Weigand and his wife doing readings and dictating letters.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The original accession is arranged in chronological divisions. Accession 2017-M-0060 is arranged into five groupings by topic or format.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers are arranged in five chronological divisions: 1935-1945, 1945-1954, 1955-1965, 1965-1974 and 1975-1983. Within these divisions, there are folders of general correspondence, topical files and selected correspondence with colleagues. There is also one audiocassette of Weigand dictating letters.

accessrestrict.p: Student recommendations are closed until January 1, 2050 as established by Yale Corporation regulations.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The accession is arranged into six groupings: correspondence, subject files, writings, personal papers, program files, and photographs and audiovisual material.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This accession received rehousing and minimal organization by Manuscripts and Archives staff. Folder titles were often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Otherwise, folder titles were supplied by staff during processing.
